subject: Two Premieres
event:
Off to San Francisco this afternoon for the premiere of GAME OF THRONES season five on Monday the 23rd, at the San Francisco Opera House.  Should be a grand affair, though the LA and NYC premieres (for seasons three and four, respectively) will be hard to top.  I look forward to seeing our old friends on the cast, and meeting some new ones.

Then it's home again, for the Santa Fe premiere of season five at the Jean Cocteau, on Saturday the 28th.   Three screenings, including the first Spanish-language screening in the morning for our Hispanic fans.

comments.article: Have fun! I too am looking forward to April 12th for the Game of Thrones season 5 premiere. If only we could just skip Easter Sunday and go straight to April 12th to the season 5 premiere.
comments.subject: game of thrones: season 5 Premiere

comments.article: I have got the feeling that each season is better than the previous one. Season five is going to be a real feast for crows.

Warmly,
Matt

comments.article: Dear George, this is something that I've been wondering for a long time. Are you able to enjoy the tv-show in same way that show watchers do(that has not read the books)? Or do you watch the show with a critical mindset that makes you dislike everything that isn't an exact adaptation of the books?
comments.subject: Something I've always wondered

comments.article: Is Patchface making an appearance this season? Bloomin' hope so.

That would be a rather awkward introduction.

"Hey guys, you remember this crazy tattooed fool spouting disguised prophecies Stannis keeps around his court? No?

He's been there the whole time.

Really.

Ahem."

On the other hand, if Victarion (played by Ray Stevenson; see: Rome, Titus Pullo, Arena scene) and the Ironborn don't get to make an appearance next season, in particular for a certain battle scene to be detailed in WoW, there will be much wailing and gnashing of teeth.

I was just looking at my old LJ account and lamenting that no one is here any more and ended up finding your (Not a) blog. Outstanding!

Ah, I miss LJ when it was in its prime. In any case, now I have a reason to come on and read again.

And yes, Season 5, April can't come soon enough...

Hello from NYC!
comments.subject: Can't wait either!

comments.subject: premiere

comments.upictitle: ryan, diesel, ty johnson, dirk vargas, ect.. ect..: Syd
comments.article: I've been reading people's posts throughout the interweb about how they're upset that the series deviates from the books. I've never worked in television, but I figure adapting gargantuan books into 10 hours with a budget and limited time would be pretty tough, especially considering the TV show can't elaborate on character's inner monologues without having them converse with someone else. Personally, I'm thankful that the books were able to be adapted to the highest quality in the first place, even if the show doesn't follow the books completely. If I want the complete story I'll hit the books again, if I want to sit down and watch the Hound and Brienne beat each other up I'll watch the show. I'm going to consume both and enjoy the ride!
Then there is the butterfly effect, small snowballs that keeps rolling and getting bigger and bigger.

How can one get tickets for the premiere at the Jean Cocteau?

It's about four hours drive for me, but it might make a great little weekend road trip. Alas, the cinema's website doesn't mention it. Is it a private event?
Any comments on the recent reburial of Richard III?
comments.subject: History

comments.article:
It's not 'recent', ser, as it hasn't happened yet. The reinterment is on Thursday of this week, though the body is currently lying in state in Leicester Cathedral, having passed through the county, including the Bosworth battlefield, yesterday (Sunday). The coffin, as you may know, was made by the late king's last known living descendant, who lives in Canada, and whose DNA was compared with that taken from the king's remains.

I have a particular interest because I've lived all my life in Leicester, and my school - now the Richard III Visitors' Centre - is adjacent to the car park where the royal body lay for 527 years, suspected only by a few academics.
comments.subject: Re: History
